p: Despite Cubaâ€™s advances in agroecology have been highlighted in the last decades, reliable statistical data on agrochemical use is scarce [ 61]. The use of agrochemicals is restricted and availability of agrochemicals on the free market is limited [ 43]. Moreover, the absence of adequate synthetic pesticides in Cuba has produced great economic losses due, for example, to thrips, severely impacting crops of beans, potatoes, and peppers [ 62]. Biological control is not enough to control this pest, and synthetic pesticides are an important component of the IPM strategy [ 63].
